phasing_details.phase_detail: Installation of Ducting and canopy system

description: Change of use from Use Class E(a) (formally A1 Retail) to E(b) (formally A3 Sale of food and drink mostly on the premises) and for the provision of a canopy and extraction system to provide cooking facilities
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: This is required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended).

The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in accordance with the materials specified on the approved plans and on the submitted application form unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The rating level of the noise determined by the cumulative sound emissions of the plant to which this permission relates shall be at least 5dBA lower than the existing background noise level at any given time of operation. The noise levels shall be measured or predicted 1m externally to any window at the nearest residential facade and the measurements and assessment shall be made according to BS 4142:2014.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy D14 of the London Plan 2021 policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The restaurant use to which this permission relates shall not open to customers outside of the following hours:11:00 to 23:00 Monday to Friday11:00 to 23:00 on Saturdays11:00 to 22:00 on Sundays and bank holidaysReason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Deliveries to the site shall not take place outside of the following hours:08:00 to 18:00 Monday to Friday08:00 to 18:00 on SaturdaysNo deliveries shall take place on Sundays or bank holidays.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The site and building works required to implement the development to which this permission relates shall not take place outside of the following hours:08:00 to 18:00 Monday to Friday08:00 to 13:00 on SaturdaysNo such work shall take place on Sundays or bank holidays.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of the development to which this permission relates, details, with calculations, of the proposed extraction system shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The submission shall include, where applicable, details of:(i) The extract fan, attenuators (it is recommended that the infill is protected by Melinex polyester film), anti-vibration mounts, high velocity cowl, filters, odour abatement and any other items of plant;(ii) The velocity of the air at final discharge and duct termination height and location(iii) The retention time of gases in the carbon filters (where applicable);(iv) A maintenance schedule;(v) A completion of an risk assessment of odour and demonstration of compliance with "Control of Odour and Noise from Commercial Kitchen Exhaust Systems" published by EMAQ+ dated September 2018The approved extraction system shall be installed on site in accordance with the approved details prior to the commencement of the restaurant use and shall be permanently maintained thereafter unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy D14 of the London Plan 2021 policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.This condition must be a pre-commencement condition because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase.

The site comprises an end-terrace dwelling.16 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development.- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Impact on trees.- Fire Safety.DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: The proposed single-storey rear extension would have a total depth of approximately 3m from the rear wall and a total pitched roof height of approximately 3.6m with an eave height of approximately 2.5m. Development of this style would not be incongruous in the vicinity of Alexandra Road as several dwellings benefit from similar rear extensions.The proposed attached side extension would not be set back from the front wall by a minimum of 500mm, as requested by Policy Guidance 35, of the Residential Design and whisltÂ officers acknowledge that the proposed development would be visible in the streetscene, development of this style would appear subordinate. Additionally, the proposed fenestration and material use would aid in making the extension appear as though it was built with the original dwelling.Â Overall, on balance, the proposed extension is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: Officers have assessed the impact on daylighting and sunlighting of the proposed rear extension, using the BRE, 45 Degree Rule and the Residential Design SPD to ensure minimum impact on neighbouring amenities.Â  Given the sitting of the proposed development in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.TreesPolicy G7 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should ensure that, wherever possible, existing trees of value are retained. If planning permission is granted that necessitates the removal of trees, there should be adequate replacement. Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 expects new development to ensure that trees that are important to the character of the area or covered by Tree Preservation Orders (TPOs) are not adversely affected.Officer comments: Officers acknowledge that the applicant has submitted a Tree Impact Plan which identifies a number of trees on site,Â including Lime Species which has a Tree Preservation Order in place. The Council's Trees and Landscapes Officer has reviewed the proposal and noted that the submitted documents do not include an arboricultural impact assessment (AIA) and/or an arboricultural method statement (AMS). Therefore, an appropriate assessment of the effects of the proposed can not be sufficiently considered.In the absence of the requested information it cannot be determined that no harm to, or loss of, retained trees which contribute positively to the character of the area would occurr.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Report which suitably addresses the provisions of Policy D12(A). For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would not in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2023), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan 2021, Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The applicant is informed that the submitted details, as set out above, are agreed and that Condition 28 (Drainage Strategy) of planning permission 21/03204/FUL is hereby discharged subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the details hereby approved.

Application SiteThe site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.ProposalErection of single storey rear extensions and conversion of single dwelling into 3nos. self contained flatsConsultation5 neighbouring properties have been notified and 6 objections from 4 different addresses have been received stating; - Access or traffic problems - Car park issues - Effects on trees - Excessive height or bulk of buildings - Fumes - Inadequate landscaping/means of enclosure - Inappropriate design/layout - Loss of light/Sunlight - Noise - Privacy - Storage of hazardous substances - Unacceptable or incompatible useAssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The principal of development;- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; - Standard of accommodation; and,- Fire safety. Principle of DevelopmentPolicy CS10 of the Council's LDF Core Strategy, 2012 sets out the Borough's housing targets as defined by the London Plan, 2021.  Policy H1 (Increasing Housing Supply) of The London Plan (2021) sets ten-year targets for net housing completions that each local planning authority should plan for. Table 4.1 sets out the 10-year targets for net housing completions in each London Borough from 2019/20 - 2028/29). The requirement for Kingston is to deliver 9,640 homes in this 10-year period which would equate to 964 net completions per annum.As there is no 5-year housing land supply, paragraph 11 of the NPPF indicates that planning permission should be granted unless (i) the application of policies in this Framework that protect areas or assets of particular importance provides a clear reason for refusing the development proposed; or (ii) any adverse impacts of doing so significantly and demonstrably outweigh the benefits when assessed against policies in this Framework taken as a whole.  These considerations should be given considerable weight in the assessment of any forthcoming planning application.The proposed development would result in a net increase of 2 Class C3 market dwellinghouses which would make a positive, albeit modest, contribution towards housing supply. Policy DM13 of the Council's LDF Core Strategy 2012 states that the Council will ensure that the housing delivered is of high quality and the most appropriate type. The Policy also states that new residential development is expected to incorporate a mix of unit sizes and types. The policy requires that 30% of the proposed units should have 3 or more bedrooms unless it can be robustly demonstrated that this would be unsuitable or unviable.Policy DM 14 of the Core Strategy seeks to resist the loss of existing accommodation (of all types) and, in particular, dwellings which are suitable for family accommodation. To protect existing family units that meet an identified need, the Council will, where necessary, limit the conversion of family units into houses in multiple occupation.The existing dwelling is a 3-bed dwelling house capable of providing family accommodation. However, the proposal would provide a 1 x 3 bed unit capable of providing family accommodation which would offset the loss.The principle of development is considered to be acceptable subject to the material planning considerations below.DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: Officers acknowledge an extension has already been permitted to the rear of the property, a further extension to this already large extension would result in an incongruous and visually dominant extension and it is considered that there would be an adverse impact on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: With regards to neighbouring amenity, officers acknowledge that a large single storey rear extension 7.9m in depth and 2.7m in height was previously permitted under planning application 22/03029/HOU dated 28.11.2022 which has been implemented. A further extension to the depth of this extension of another 2.7 metres is considered to be unacceptable due the undue sense of enclosure and overbearing appearance that the further depth would create to the adjoining neighbour. Overall, it is considered that the proposed development would adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance.Standard of AccommodationPolicy D6 (Housing Quality and Standards) of the London Plan (2021) sets out that housing development should be of high-quality design and provide adequately sized rooms (as set out in Table 3.1 of the London Plan 2021) with comfortable and functional layouts which are fit for purpose and meet the needs of Londoners without differentiating between tenures.With regards to private amenity space, a minimum of 10sqm should be provided. Private amenity space would only be provided for two out of the three flats which would not meet the minimum requirementsProposed sections have been provided to demonstrate that internal floor levels would be at least 2.5m in height for at least 75% of the Gross Internal Area (GIA).  With regards to the proposed Studio flat, officers note that due to its position within the property, this flat would lack privacy and defensible space as it would front onto the garden for Flat 1. There would also be a  poor levels of outlook.  It is also unclear whether Flat 1 would achieve sufficient levels of daylight or sunlight given the orientation of the property and deep floor plates. No Daylight & Sunlight Assessment has been submitted.Overall, Officers find the highest standard of accommodation has not been achieved, and the proposal fails to meet the standards and requirements set in Policy D6 of the London Plan,Nationally Described Space Standards and the RBK Residential Design Guide.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a floor plan showing some fire alarms and assembly points not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions should permission be granted. For this reason, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be contrary to the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Details required for Conditions 4 (Construction Management Plan) and 15 (PEA) of planning permission 23/01059/FUL (Demolition of dwelling and erection of 1no. 3 bed replacement dwelling, and erection of 3no. 4 bed dwellings to rear with new access road)Condition 4: Construction Management Plan (CMP)  confirms that the proposed development will be undertaken over a duration of 48 weeks and the developer has briefly elaborated on the work activities and programme in the CMP.All construction activities will be carried out from Monday - Friday within the hours of 8am - 6pm and Saturday; 8am - 1pm. No work will be carried out on Sundays and bank holidays.The developer notes the presence of the nearby St Paul's School, which is also located on Orchard Road. As such they (Developer) will ensure there are no deliveries between 8am - 9am and 2.45pm - 3.45pm, during term times. This is an acceptable measure.According to the developer, the majority of deliveries will come from Buildbase in Cox lane, near the site and the delivery route which will be agreed with Buildbase, will be via Kingston Road, left to the Tolworth Roundabout on the A3 and to the A3 Hook Road Roundabout from where the delivery vehicles will connect to the Orchard Road site. However, it can be observed that the Buildbase store is approx. 4 minutes drive from the site, compared to the proposed A3 route, which may appear to be longer. As such, the contractor/supplier should be requested to strictly use the proposed A3 route and avoid going through the short 4 minute internal route, which goes through mostly residential areas. Map sketches have been provided to show the routes.The CMP indicates that connections for relevant utilities will be required. According to the developer, the relevant utility companies will apply for the appropriate street works licences and any relevant traffic management will be undertaken by them.The location of the materials storage area, welfare unit and car parking for contractor staff, have been provided in a location map.The CMP has outlined satisfactory control measures for dust and noise on the site.The Highways team have confirmed that the CMP covers the key requirements for the proposed development and as such it is considered acceptable. Â

The proposed site 'Speirs House' is categorised as Care/Nursing Home, the 'Ownership Certificate A' has been signed, please confirm the 'Ownership Certificate A' is correct, otherwise please amend the whole application form with correct 'Ownership Certificate'.
